results.title: Grumpy old man
results.creator_credit: Richard Bailey, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI
results.brief_description: Richard Bailey has nudged and niggled people and he’s had some success, especially on the asbestos issue. A heart attack in 2003 meant that Bailey couldn’t be as active anymore, so he decided to direct his energies elsewhere.

results.title: Dead man
results.creator_credit: Jim Jarmusch, Demetra MacBride, Pandora Films and 12-Gauge Productions
results.brief_description: Filmed in stunning black and white by cinematographer Robby Muller, Jim Jarmusch has established a surreal tone for this visually poetic meditation on life and death. Dead Man is the tale of William Blake (Johnny Depp), a naive Ohio accountant who travels west to a primitive frontier outpost called Machine in expectation of a job that’s already been filled. Within a short space of time Blake is involved in a showdown and finds himself wounded and on the run. Pursued by vicious bounty hunters, Blake is looked after by Nobody (Gary Farmer) an Eastern-educated Indian who believes his new friend is the dead British poet and mystic William Blake.Gradually, Blake comes to fulfill his designated role as the most wanted man in this corner of the west, all the while preparing for life’s ultimate journey. Accompanied by the haunting music of Neil Young, cameo roles by Robert Mitchum, John Hurt and Iggy Pop, and a strong cast including Lance Henriksen, Michael Wincott, Mili Avital and Gabriel Byrne, makes Dead Man an experience not to be missed. Note: Widescreen format.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Jim Jarmusch, Demetra MacBride, Pandora Films and 12-Gauge Productions

results.title: A Little bit of willpower
results.creator_credit: Leanda Bunn, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI
results.brief_description: Kicked out of home at the age of 15 and struggling with depression, Leanda Bunn still managed to complete her VCE, find accommodation and be independent thanks to a few very special people in her life and a lot of willpower.

results.title: Crossenvale stories : Digital Storytelling project
results.brief_description: Eight residents of the Crossendale estate in Echuca in Northern Victoria share their personal stories as part of a Digital Storytelling workshop. While the subjects vary, the topic is mostly centred around the things that lie closest to the participants’ hearts.
results.description: Eight residents of the Crossendale estate in Echuca in Northern Victoria share their personal stories as part of a Digital Storytelling workshop. While the subjects vary, the topic is mostly centred around the things that lie closest to the participants’ hearts.

results.title: The Wolf
results.creator_credit: Beverly Bailey, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI
results.brief_description: It was Beverly Bailey’s husband who suggested she take the trip to England and Canada to meet his family. As Bailey disappeared through the airport door her husband wondered if he’d said the wrong thing.

results.title: Where my heart lies
results.creator_credit: Vicki Baker, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI
results.brief_description: Vicki Baker, mother of three, grew up in the bush but eventually had to move to town to find employment. She recalls her childhood days of family and the freedom of running through the bush with the wind in her hair and not a care in the world.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Vicki Baker, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI

results.title: Dead Heart (A) (Captioned)
results.creator_credit: Nick Parsons, Helen Watts, Bryan Brown and Film Finance Corporation Australia
results.brief_description: Constable Ray Lorkin (Bryan Brown) struggles to maintain law and order in the Aboriginal community of Wala Wala. The geographical isolation of the community is heightened by the incompatability between “white man’s justice” and indigenous tribal law. The situation reaches crisis point when a young Aboriginal (Aaron Pedersen) allows the white woman with whom he is having an affair to view a sacred initiation site. “Dead Heart” presents an honest portrayal of the conflict between two cultures and laws and the consequences that can occur. Parsons also wrote the script.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Nick Parsons, Helen Watts, Bryan Brown and Film Finance Corporation Australia

results.title: Dead End Drive-in (AFC)
results.creator_credit: Brian Trenchard-Smith, A Williams, New South Wales Film Corporation and Springvale Productions
results.brief_description: Futuristic satirical comedy which revolves around the use of drive-in theatres as internment camps for outcasts from society where the unemployed and weak are fed junk food, music and bad films. When the film’s main character finds himself there by accident, he is obsessed by a desire to escape and find a new sense of purpose in his life.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Brian Trenchard-Smith, A Williams, New South Wales Film Corporation and Springvale Productions

results.title: Our land, our truth = Debout sur leur terre
results.creator_credit: Maurice Bulbulian, Jean Dansereau and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: Made in collaboration with the Inuit Tungavingat Nunamini, this film focuses on those dissident members of the Inuit community who rejected the agreement signed on November 11, l975, between the Northern Quebec Inuit Association, the Quebec and federal governments, the James Bay Energy Corporation, the James Bay Development Corporation, Hydro-Quebec and the Grand Council of the Crees, which took away Native rights to a territory of almost one million square kilometres. By their words and actions, the dissident Inuit of Povungnituk, Ivujivik and Sugluk express their strong desire to retain their land and their traditions. The filmmakers go into their homes, on the ice and the sea to record first-hand the lives of these northern people. In French and Inuit with no subtitles.
